subject: Allow a subtranslator to use a field from the parent table as an id
commit_message:
Allow a subtranslator to use a field from the parent table as an id

In the previous version, a subtranslator always computed a new id based on the
subtable's content.  This change allows a subtranslator to use a column from
the parent table in the subtable's id column.

For example, the following translator:
  list_translator = {'translation-type': 'LIST',
                     'table-name': 'subtable',
                     'parent-key': 'foreign-key',
                     'val-col': 'val_col',
                     'translator': self.value_trans}
  translator = {'translation-type': 'HDICT', 'table-name': 'testtable',
                'selector-type': 'DICT_SELECTOR',
                'field-translators': ({'fieldname': 'foreign-key',
                                       'translator': self.value_trans},
                                      {'fieldname': 'foo',
                                       'translator': list_translator})}

Would turn the following objects
 {'foreign-key': 100, 'foo': (1, 2)}
 {'foreign-key': 101, 'foo': (3, 4)}

into these tables:

  testtable  subtable
  100        100, 1
  101        100, 2
             101, 3
             101, 4

subject: Check server group policy on migrate/evacuate
commit_message:
Check server group policy on migrate/evacuate

This patch changes server group checking in the instance group setup.
Previously, it checked for the presence of the 'group' scheduler hint
as an indication that the instance was a member of a group.  However,
that hint is only present on initial boot.  It is not present when the
scheduler is being used to pick a destination for a migration or
evactuate.

The updated logic checks the database to see if the instance is a
member of a group.  For performance reasons, it only does this is
server group functionality is enabled in the scheduler (group filters
are enabled).

This change makes it so server group policy enforcement will still
occur for migrations and evactuations, instead of only on first boot.

It also adds the call to setup_instance_group in evacuate, resize,
cold migrate and live migrate methods because now it is possible to
access the group setup.

subject: Implements: blueprint neutron-ipam
commit_message:
Implements: blueprint neutron-ipam

NeutronIPAM as IPAM subsystem

This implements NeutronIPAM that has been proposed in the
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/neutron-ipam.

The goal is to create NeutronIPAM as a pluggable IPAM subsytem
so that any 3rd party vendor can create her own IPAM drvier
by inherting interfaces defined in NeutronIPAM and adding
the vendor specific behaviors that utilize the vendor's
own external IPAM backends.

IPAM subsystem allows a 3rd party IPAM driver to extend the
capability of managing networks/subnets, fixed/floating IP
addresses, and DNS records.

IPAM subsystem creates "ipam" folder under neutron.
The folder contains base.py that provides interfaces for
IPAM management classes.

There are four interface classes defined in the base module.

*IPAMManager* is the main class that defines IPAM driver
behaviors and make use of business logics that are defined
in the three controller classes: IPAMController,
DHCPController, and DNSController

IPAMController enables network management capabiltiy,
DHCPController DHCP management, and DNSController
DNS record managements.

"drivers" folder is created right under the "ipam".
There exists "neutron_ipam" module as the default
neutron driver. The module has NeutronIPAM that
implements IPAMManager, NeutronDHCPController that
implements DHCPController, NeutronDNSController that
implements DNSController.

A 3rd party vendor can create her own driver by creating
a vendor folder under "drivers" and create a driver by
implementing IPAMController, DHCPController, and
DNSController and also by inheriting NeutronIPAM,
NeutronDHCPController, and NeutronDNSController classes.

Change-Id: I7cb4fa2a5c73944b986554196e1001166c148821

subject: VMware: Propagate static targets on attach_volume
commit_message:
VMware: Propagate static targets on attach_volume

As soon as a user attaches a Cinder iSCSI volume to a VM,
the host where the VM is running establishes a connection with
the remote iSCSI target. This is good as long as vMotion is not part of
the picture. Indeed, vMotion will be a no-op if the target host
where the VM should be relocated doesn't know about the iSCSI target.
This patch addresses the issue by starting an asynchronous operation
on attach_volume() which will propagate the static targets to all the
hosts of the cluster.
The operation is asynchronous due to the fact that the scan operation
might take a couple of seconds.
If the compute node goes down when progagating, the next attach_volume
will propagate again.
vCenter deduplicates the same static targets automatically so we are
sure
that we always have a set of unique static targets.
This patch doesn't leverage discovery addresses but only static targets
which has the advantage of avoiding noise of unused targets in the SCSI
topology.

Closes-Bug: #1330758

subject: Introduce changes necessary for generic volume migration
commit_message:
Introduce changes necessary for generic volume migration

This patch contains the core driver changes needed to make generic
volume migration possible.  By itself, no changes to the existing logic
for volume migration are introduced.  The intent is to keep the original
behaviour intact while allowing certain drivers that cannot attach
volumes locally to still participate in volume migration.

To allow this functionality, an 'is_attachable' function is added to the
volume driver definition.  This property indicates whether the volume
can be attached locally to the host and expose a path to the resulting
block device.  A driver author can override this and return False if
a driver cannot attach its volumes in a way that exposes a block device
path.  Doing so will cause the volume copy routine (copy_volume_data) to
use file I/O instead of calling out to `dd`.  The driver author is
expected to provide an implementation of open_volume() that returns
a file object capable of proxying I/O requests to the underlying storage
backend.

An RPC call for 'is_attachable' is added to allow querying of remote
volume capabilities.

The default volume open and close routines are currently unimplemented
and are the next step in this series.  The open routine will return
a file handle defined by the path to the block device.  This will allow
drivers like RBD which do not support attachment to migrate to and from
drivers which do support attachment, such as LVM.

Related-Blueprint: generic-volume-migration

subject: Include timestamp in diskfile create
commit_message:
Include timestamp in diskfile create

In all known cases when creating a new DiskFileWriter with DiskFile.create the
final timestamp of the object to be created is known ahead of time, but not
exposed to the DiskFile implementation until the end of the write via metadata
in the call to put.

The timestamp of the newly created object is an important detail to the
default DiskFile implementation in it's handling of consistency and it's
on-disk layout; but the file system based implementation can avoid requring
this core piece of information until the very last call to the DiskFileWriter
because of the under-lying datastores support for atomic move.

For datastores which do not support atomic move (such as key value stores) it
can greatly simplify failure mode recovery if the final timestamp/version of
the object created is known before the very call to write.

With the introduction of the Timestamp class; there's a very small
simplification in the core implementation that falls out of not having to
reparse the string form of the timestamp provided in metadata to construct the
internalized timestamp used when creating the final on-disk name.

Because a new previously undescribed optional keyword is pushed into
DiskFile.create by swift.obj.server.ObjectController.PUT this change is
Backwards incompatible with existing implementations of DiskFile that did not
have the lucky foresight to accept **kwargs in their implementation of create
(e.g.  swift.obj.mem_diskfile.DiskFile.create).  When testing with the next
version of swift that includes this change diskfile maintainers who want to
continue to support the latest version will need to accept the new signature
for create but will not be required to adopt it and can maintain backwards
compatibility with older versions of swift simply by ignoring it and using the
timestamp provided in metadata as always.

subject: Add openstack-infra/puppet-httpd
commit_message:
Add openstack-infra/puppet-httpd

We currently pin to puppetlabs-apache 0.0.4 (released 09-05-2012).

The main difference with later versions is that they stopped
supporting using a template for vhost configuration; rather moving
various parts of configuratoin as option arguments.

This means that to convert to any later version of the module it
requires going through all of our templates; currently something like:

---
[system-config]$ find | grep vhost.erb
./modules/logstash/templates/logstash.vhost.erb
./modules/logstash/templates/kibana.vhost.erb
./modules/openstack_project/templates/puppetboard/puppetboard.vhost.erb
./modules/openstack_project/templates/logs.vhost.erb
./modules/openstack_project/templates/status.vhost.erb
./modules/openstack_project/templates/logs-dev.vhost.erb
./modules/drupal/templates/drupal.vhost.erb
./modules/gerrit/templates/gerrit.vhost.erb
./modules/meetbot/templates/vhost.erb
./modules/openstackid/templates/vhost.erb
./modules/jenkins/templates/jenkins.vhost.erb
./modules/cgit/templates/git.vhost.erb
./modules/zuul/templates/zuul.vhost.erb
./modules/etherpad_lite/templates/etherpadlite.vhost.erb
./modules/mailman/templates/mailman.vhost.erb
./modules/graphite/templates/graphite.vhost.erb
---

figuring out what they do, figuring out what arguments to translate
this to and redeploying all of these without breaking anything.

Even if we want to upgrade to the latest versions, which is a matter
of some debate, doing it all at once is almost impossible.

This creates openstack-infra/puppet-httpd which will be a fork of
0.0.4.  This can cover us both ways -- we can upgrade piecemeal, or
stay with the status-quo and add small, appropriate enhancements to
this module without having to upgrade the whole world.

The name was chosen by committee [1] to avoid conflict with the
original module (should we wish to use that in parallel) and to avoid
any confusion that this might be used to deploy apache for OpenStack
projects in general.

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/infra/2014/infra.2014-11-11-19.00.html

subject: Add parameter to customize Qpid receiver capacity
commit_message:
Add parameter to customize Qpid receiver capacity

In Qpid rpc backend, receiver capacity is 1 and is hardcoding.
User can not customize it. This patch adds a parameter to make
user can specify receiver capacity in conf file.

- Reference about Receiver Capacity(Prefetch) from Qpid Doc
By default, receiver requests the next message from the server
in response to each fetch call, resulting in messages being
sent to the receiver one at a time. As in the case of sending,
it is often desirable to avoid this roundtrip for each message.
This can be achieved by allowing the receiver to prefetch messages
in anticipation of fetch calls being made. The receiver needs to
be able to store these prefetched messages, the number it can hold
is controlled by the receivers capacity.
